Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History: The Greek Key and Divine Attributes in Modern Dress
The Art of Classical Greece (ca. 480–323 B.C.)
The Chiton, Peplos, and Himation in Modern Dress
Description: Copy of a Greek relief of ca. 425–400 B.C. attributed to KallimachosMaenads were mythical women inspired by the god of wine, Dionysos, to abandon their homes and families and roam the mountains and forests, singing and dancing in a state of ecstatic frenzy. This figure, wearing an ivy wreath and carrying a thyrsos (fennel stalk) bedecked with ivy leaves and berries, moves forward, trancelike, her drapery swirling about her. She was copied from a famous relief of dancing maenads dated to the late fifth century B.C., when Euripides portrayed the manic devotées of Dionysos in his play the Bacchae.
